report_title: Industry Research: Livestock Production Support Services in the US
executive_summary: Operators in the industry are primarily hired by livestock farms to perform support services, such as boarding horses, administering vaccinations and testing milk products. Demand for these services depends on the level of activity in downstream livestock industries and these markets' propensities to outsource support services to external companies. Rising per capita meat consumption has encouraged many livestock farmers to increase levels of production, while strong fed livestock prices have further aided growth in these downstream industries. Over the past five years, industry revenue has been falling at a CAGR of 1.1% and is expected to reach $5.1 billion in 2023, when revenue is projected to fall to 2.1%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Livestock Farms' and Ranches' Production has Fallen
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Industry revenue is highly dependent on the performance of downstream livestock production industries. While this industry provides some services to the general public, such as animal boarding and pedigree record keeping, livestock farms and ranches constitute the industry's most crucial downstream markets. As drought conditions have drove down livestock production and the price of feed has rose, demand from livestock farms and ranches has faltered.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Demand from Horse Owners has Risen Slightly
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Industry performance is sensitive to changes in demand from equine professionals and enthusiasts. As buying and caring for a horse is considered by most to be both expensive and highly discretionary, demand from this market is dependent on overall levels of disposable income in the United States. Per capita disposable income has seen an overall rise in recent years, supporting demand from horse owners.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Industry Comprises Many Diverse Small Players
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry offers a wide array of services that see varied levels of performance. The industry comprises mostly nonemployers, with each performing a small share of the services included in this industry. Different support services are more common in certain areas, with specific regions of the country often being suited to different types of agriculture.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Support Services Can Be Brought In-House
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While it is often cost-effective for small-scale livestock farmers to outsource support services to industry operators, some invest in the human and physical capital needed to conduct these services in-house. As farmers that choose to operate their own livestock support services typically require small loans to purchase new technologies and equipment, rising access to credit is expected to challenge the Livestock Production Support Services industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Livestock Industry Performance is Set to Be Tepid
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As meat prices decline and weather conditions become increasingly volatile in coming years, demand from livestock farms and ranches is expected to weaken. Both Beef Cattle Production (IBISWorld report 11211) and Hog & Pig Farming (IBISWorld report 11221) are set to see slight declines moving forward, weakening their demand for support services.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Horse Support Services Should Remain a Source of Revenue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Moving forward, demand from horse and other equine production is set to continue to see growth, supporting the industry. Continued growth in per capita disposable income will benefit consumers' demand for horses.

industry_definition: This industry includes companies that mainly provide support services for raising livestock. Livestock is a term used to describe animals, such as cattle, goats, hogs, horses, poultry and sheep, which have been domestically raised for meat, milk, wool and work. Support services provided to livestock producers include breeding services, pedigree record services and vaccination. Activities related to aquaculture are excluded.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

opportunities: Demand from horse and other equine production

key_trends: Industry revenue is highly dependent on the performance of downstream livestock production industries
Industry performance is sensitive to changes in demand from equine professionals and enthusiasts
The industry offers a wide array of services that see varied levels of performance
Rising access to credit is expected to challenge the Livestock Production Support Services industry

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment accounts for the share of industry revenue that comes from beef cattle farms. In addition to breeding and vaccination services, this segment demands branding, bull testing and spraying services from industry operators. As levels of beef production rise and cattle farmers increasingly aim to get more meat from fewer animals, revenue from this market segment is expected to grow marginally in coming years.

This segment accounts for revenue derived from support services provided to horses and horse owners. Unlike livestock animals, which are typically boarded on farms dedicated to producing meat, dairy, eggs or wool, horses are generally boarded in stables or other boarding facilities that enable them to be easily accessed by their owners. The cost of horse boarding facilities can vary significantly and often depends on the facility's location and quality. Customers in this market segment also require farrier services such as horseshoeing and hoof trimming. Revenue from this segment has increased due to the increasing costs of caring for a horse and due to a slight uptick in horse herd numbers.

This segment accounts for revenue from dairy farms. The production of milk requires testing and analysis to measure fat and solid contents that distinguish types of milk. Operators engaged in livestock production support services include dairy herd improvement associations, which advise dairy farms on best practices and new regulations.

This segment accounts for revenue from poultry and egg farms, which include chicken, turkey and egg producers. The cleaning of poultry houses and the catching of poultry for loading into transport trailers represent specialized services offered to this market.

This segment accounts for revenue from hog and pig farmers. As nearly every part of a pig is processed into foodstuffs, producers constantly seek to breed animals that will yield more meat, generating demand for spraying, vaccinations and other industry services that improve the health and physical development of hogs and pigs.

This segment accounts for revenue from other markets, including sheep farms. Sheep farms are estimated to make up the smallest market for support service providers. US production of wool from sheep has fallen significantly as less expensive imports have continued to undercut domestic prices. In turn, US sheep farmers have sought fewer sheep-shearing services, causing demand for industry services to decline.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment accounts from revenue from animal boarding services, which are mostly supplied to horses and other recreational animals. Revenue from these services has declined due to reduced horse ownership within the United States. While disposable income levels have risen, the cost of caring for a horse has increased significantly as well. This discrepancy has led many horse owners to sell their horses or invest in more affordable forms of boarding, causing this segment's share of total industry revenue to decline.
This segment accounts for revenue from other services, including shearing and livestock spraying services.

This segment accounts for revenue from breeding services. Wide-ranging breeding services include semen collection, artificial insemination of livestock, reproductive flushing services, bull testing stations and specialist stud services.

This segment accounts for revenue from dairy support services. Service providers in this category fall into two groups: those offering milk testing for butterfat and milk solids and dairy herd improvement associations.

This segment accounts for revenue from livestock health services. Though farmers typically engage trained veterinarians to maintain the health of their livestock, industry operators also provide a small amount of healthcare services to livestock animals, including administering vaccinations and conducting serologic tests to determine an animal's health.

This segment accounts for revenue from farrier services. Horse owners often require farrier services such as shoeing and hoof trimming for their horses. Horses' hooves need proper care, especially if they are continually bearing the weight of both themselves and their riders. Hooves can wear down, grow disproportionately and splinter. Farriers trim and shoe horses' hooves to correct these problems.
Livestock spraying services are used to limit the spread of diseases by safeguarding animals against ticks, fleas and flies.

tier_2_buyers: Beef Cattle Production in the US
Hog & Pig Farming in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for many support services can be seasonal or cyclical, depending on the service provided. For operators servicing livestock producers, demand often peaks during calving and lambing periods when time constraints are tight and the workload is heavy. Shearing services are also cyclical. Most sheep in the United States are only shorn once or twice a year, leading to high levels of production in short timeframes.

Additionally, demand for support services is correlated with overall levels of livestock production, since an increase in production activity will raise the volume of support services required. The level of activity in livestock production industries is a function of many factors. Resource allocation decisions made by farmers depend largely on the profitability of various agricultural activities. An increase in returns from livestock production relative to returns from crop production is likely to encourage farmers to increase their livestock inventories. The number of livestock animals raised is also affected by the presence of animal diseases and the consumption of animal products.

Similar to the level of livestock production, demand for industry services is also influenced by the number of horses in need of shoeing, boarding, vaccinations and other support services. While this figure is largely determined by the total number of horses in the United States, which has been in constant decline for several years, levels of disposable income also affect the amount that horse professionals and enthusiasts are willing to spend on industry services. Given the expensive and highly discretionary nature of owning a horse, US consumers are typically more willing to purchase horses and pay for their upkeep when levels of per capita disposable income are high, which generates demand for industry operators.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Due to the localized nature of industry services, companies in the Livestock Production Support Services industry operate almost exclusively within the domestic market. Additionally, natural and geographic barriers make most services provided by this industry inappropriate for exporting. While artificial insemination services and the provision of cattle semen are exported by this industry's breeding services segment, these exports account for less than 0.1% of total industry revenue.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast leads the country in terms of chicken and turkey production, along with a large proportion of egg production. The Southeast leads the country in the number of horses sold, thereby presenting a greater opportunity for higher-margin, horse-related support services. Florida is the region's largest state for livestock production support services.

Compared with establishments in the Southeast region, industry establishments in the West experience a relatively high level of concentration. The West features a high level of sheep production and an average level of egg production. This region contains a high percentage of dairy product production. California is the region's largest dairy-producing state and contains the highest number of dairy cows. As a result, California is also the largest state in the country in terms of industry establishments.

The Mid-Atlantic region accounts for the third largest share of all livestock support service locations. The region ranks third in the number of chicken and turkey production establishments, and also contains a high concentration of dairy farms. The region exhibits a relatively low share of horse production and contains relatively few beef and sheep production locations. The state with the highest concentration of industry establishments in the Mid-Atlantic region is New York.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Many companies in this industry, such as operators engaged in sheep dipping and livestock spraying, employ farm chemicals. This practice has given rise to concerns about the environmental effect of chemicals in livestock production. The use of pesticides by this industry is regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).

Various service providers must comply with regulations enforced by the Food and Drugs Administration (FDA). This public health agency is part of the Public Health Services and operates within the Department of Human Health and Services. Its chief responsibility is the enforcement of the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act.

The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) is primarily responsible for the implementation and enforcement of the Farm Act, though this body also implements several other laws. For example, the USDA governs organic meat production by the National Organic Program (NOP), which was signed in to law in 2002, designating uniform standards for organic production of crops and livestock.

Among the horse related segments of this industry, horse breeders and owners are required by some states to register their horse with the state to qualify as a state-bred horse. Additionally, horse breeders are required to be licensed by some states before they are permitted to enter into the market.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Industry assistance level is low and steady.
Competition level is high and increasing.

factors_decreased_barrier.factor: Globalization level is low and steady.

basis_points.basis_description: The price of support services is a key competitive factor.
Industry operators compete on the quality of service they provide.
Industry operators compete on the basis of reputation.

concentration_points.concentration_description: In most cases, it is difficult for operators to generate economies of scale.
Operators prefer to specialize rather than become one-stop shops.
Demand is divided geographically, diluting concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages claim the industry's largest share of revenue
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages account for the largest share of total industry revenue, due primarily to the labor-intensive nature of livestock production support services. Nonemploying owner-operators are estimated to constitute 92.8% of total industry enterprises in 2021, which bolsters the portion of industry revenue dedicated to wages as owner-operators typically experience minimal overhead costs, compensating themselves.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases are significant for some operators
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases are expected to account for 25.0% of industry revenue in 2023. Many segments of the industry incur significant purchase costs. From lab supplies for high-end breeding specialists to feed for boarders, purchases consistently form the second-largest cost component of the average operator's total revenue.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low levels of innovation limit threat from new technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators from new technologies disrupting their operations. However, a low rate of growth in technology can also create exposure for incumbents as the trajectory of innovation in other markets could lead to unforeseen competitive disadvantages.
An accommodative structure can create a situation where small entrants can focus on less profitable albeit innovative industry entry points.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Volatility in this industry results from fluctuations in the level of livestock production and market conditions for agricultural products. Livestock production levels are affected by a range of factors including weather conditions, the presence of animal disease and meat consumption levels.
Per capita consumption of products such as beef, pork and poultry have remained relatively consistent, yielding low levels of revenue volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The Livestock Production Support Services industry experiences a degree of technological disruption via the development of stronger antibiotics. Stronger antibiotics and other medicines will equate to fewer sick animals and eventually lower orders of industry products.

A major development in livestock branding has been the introduction of electronic tagging. In this process, a radio transponder inserted behind an animal's ear records details on the animal's birth and branding, veterinary treatment, weaning date and carcass information including fat cover.

Advances in animal pharmaceuticals can substantially improve the quality of care being provided by operators engaged in livestock vaccination, especially in the poultry segment. So far, these vaccines have significantly extended the life of birds and increased bird health.

Research in biotechnology is currently underway in livestock breeding segment, and there have been several significant advances in this technology in recent years. For example, the bovine genome has been sequenced by a group of research organizations with contributions from the US federal government and industry bodies.

Operators working in the shearing services segment have pursued biological harvesting for several years. Biological harvesting involves using a natural protein to break the link between the wool fiber and the sheep, with the wool captured in a net beneath the sheep.

Though not necessarily a nascent technology, some rural areas of the US are still not serviced by broadband internet access. Overall, access to broadband has the potential to increase operational efficiencies for downstream farmers.

FAQs.question: Are your sales dependent on the overall health of the economy?
FAQs.answer: Rising overall incomes will enable downstream customers to better afford the purchase of livestock support services, particularly those services for equines. When agricultural prices are low, livestock support service providers will see a decline in demand due to a lack of affordability.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or operate in a diverse range of industry segments?
FAQs.answer: Cross-segment competition can be extremely high and often cost-prohibitive. Most livestock support service providers will specialize in one type of service, such as sheep shearing in order to maximize returns. However, overexposure to just one downstream market is how many operators have suffered during the pandemic due to a downturn in said market as a result of COVID-19. Membership organizations such as the Missouri Pork Association, the National Cattlemen's Beef Association and the American Quarter Horse Association represent the interests of livestock farmers. These organizations help maintain the health of major downstream industries, ensuring a viable market for livestock support service providers.

FAQs.question: How does volatility of input prices affect your operations?
FAQs.answer: Increases in the price of agricultural inputs will constrain demand for livestock support services. Low agricultural prices can stymie demand because downstream farmers are not optimistic about future conditions, potentially cutting herd numbers and weakening demand for industry services.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to key downstream markets?
FAQs.answer: Operators located near downstream markets and end customers will be afforded cost savings. Operators that are not located near key end markets will not have consistent demand for their services. Overall, it is uncompetitive for industry operators to compete with one another outside of specific service locales.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technologies?
FAQs.answer: Service providers that adopt the most recent technologies will exhibit efficiency gains and labor cost savings. Advanced tagging technology can provide full medical histories of livestock, reducing clerical error and streamlining operations.

FAQs.question: Does your company utilize electronic data interchange technology?
FAQs.answer: Service providers that adopt electronic data management systems will exhibit higher operational efficiencies. Electronic data management software can encourage strong supply chain management, protecting service providers from future cost increases.

FAQs.question: Have you had any regulatory expenses that have significantly impacted profitability?
FAQs.answer: Service providers that do not comply with regulations surrounding organic food production are subject to severe fines and penalties. Noncompliant operators will damage public perceptions, hindering revenue growth.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of the shifting regulatory landscape?
FAQs.answer: Service providers that are trendsetters will experience a boost in public opinion, helping revenue growth. Service providers that coordinate with industry associations will be better positioned to adapt to the changing regulatory landscape.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins vary by segment and service providers that specialize in one particular industry segment will see wider margins. Service providers that enter into long-term supply contracts will have more stable revenue and lower purchase costs, increasing profit margins.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for the seasonality of cash flows?
FAQs.answer: Demand for livestock support services is cyclical and seasonal. Service providers that switch between operations will have more consistent business. Service providers operating in just one segment will exhibit revenue declines when seasonal demand slackens.

FAQs.question: How does your establishment attract customers? How do you monitor your customers' satisfaction levels? How do you respond to customer complaints?
FAQs.answer: A good reputation is important for any company providing support services because referrals are an important source of demand. Overall, industry operators who provide strong services and a quality reputation will succeed since most services are considered substitutable by any other industry operator.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure that equipment is reliable and up-to-date? Does your company provide services that require special technology?
FAQs.answer: Reliable and up-to-date equipment improves quality, raises productivity and increases efficiency of services. This is a particularly important success factor for operators providing breeding and artificial insemination services.

FAQs.question: What livestock industries are you located close to? What methods are in place to retain customers? How is your reputation for timely service?
FAQs.answer: Locating near key livestock industries enables service providers to build client bases, customer loyalty and provide timely assistance.

FAQs.question: How do you respond to varying trends in per capita disposable income? Are certain services more sensitive to fluctuations in disposable income?
FAQs.answer: As overall levels of per capita disposable income increase, more consumers can afford to purchase horses and related support services.

FAQs.question: What trends in meat consumption have you noticed? How can your company adapt when per capita meat consumption is low?
FAQs.answer: As consumer demand for meat products increases, downstream livestock production industries typically increase production and invest more heavily in livestock support services.

FAQs.question: What is the biggest input cost for your company? What impact does the price of feed have on your company's funds for industry services?
FAQs.answer: High feed costs will erode demand for industry services due to the fact that farmers are expending more resources on animal feed.
